origination.corpname: Planned Parenthood League, Inc. of Detroit.

did.abstract: Detroit, Michigan chapter of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, founded in 1932 as the Detroit Chapter of the Michigan Birth Control League. Minutes, correspondence, reports, surveys, newsletters, and printed material document the efforts of the Planned Parenthood League to provide birth control information and services to residents of the Detroit area

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This record group was deposited with the library, April 30, 1982. Ownership of the records has been retained by the Planned Parenthood League. Donor no. 6613

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Planned Parenthood League, Inc. of Detroit Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Detroit Chapter of the Birth Control League of Michigan was organized in 1932, one year after the founding of the Michigan Birth Control League. There had been organized efforts to provide contraceptive information in the Detroit area in the previous decade: in 1922, Margaret Sanger had lectured on the subject; and in 1927 the Mother's Clinic opened its doors to young women desiring contraceptive information. Two additional birth control clinics were established in 1931, at Harper Hospital and Woman's Hospital.

The Detroit league underwent several name changes in the succeeding decades. In 1934, following the lead of the state league with which it was affiliated, the Detroit organization changed its name to the Detroit Chapter of the Maternal Health League of Michigan. In 1942, it became the Detroit Chapter, Michigan League for Planned Parenthood. The name was again changed in 1944, to the Detroit League for Planned Parenthood, Inc. When the Michigan maternal Health League dissolved in 1953, the Detroit league became an affiliate of Planned Parenthood Federation of America. Finally, in 1960 the Detroit and Oakland County leagues merged to form Planned Parenthood League, Inc.

In its early years the organization concentrated on operating birth control clinics and providing contraceptive information; it assumed responsibility for financing the Harper Clinic in 1933. The league soon expanded its education and publicity activities, establishing an information booth at the Michigan State Fair for the first time in 1939. In the 1940's and 1950's the league attempted to reach industrial workers by distributing leaflets through their unions and mailing brochures to women in neighborhoods served by the clinics.

Although the concept of birth control gained increasing acceptance from the 1940's onward, Planned Parenthood continued to face opposition, particularly from religious groups. It was not until 1967, after years of applying, that Planned Parenthood was finally accepted as a non-financial member of the United Community Services of metropolitan Detroit.

Population control was a major goal of the organization, but through the years Planned Parenthood broadened its program to include the goals of child spacing and maternal and child health. A project in venereal disease detection was begun in 1966; it later became a regular clinic service. In 1969 Infertility Diagnostic and Counseling Service was started and in 1971 a vasectomy service was offered. From 1969 through 1976 Planned Parenthood League received grants form the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare to be used in conjunction with the Detroit and Wayne County health departments for family planning services. In 1972 Planned Parenthood League turned the granteeship over to the Southeastern Michigan Family Planning Project (SEMFPP), a newly-formed community corporation comprised of service-providing agencies. Planned Parenthood League terminated its federal family planning grant in 1976, but maintained its clinical facilities and educational programs. While the board had voted in 1949 not to provide clinical services for "premarital women" or unwed mothers, by the 1970's the league was even targeting many of its programs toward teenagers. After the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, Planned Parenthood League initiated abortion counseling and referral services. Despite periodic financial crises, Planned Parenthood League continued through the 1970's to provide sex education, reproductive health care information, and medical services, and to work toward its goal of gaining universal acceptance of the notion of family planning.

arrangement.p:
The Planned Parenthood League, Inc., records dates from 1932 to 1979 and measure 8.5 linear feet. The records are arranged in eight series:
Histories (1943-1949)
Board of Directors Records (1932-1979)
Committee Records (1959-1978)
Correspondence and Memoranda (1966-1979)
Medical Material (1932-1978)
Planned Parenthood Federation of America (1954-1978)
Michigan Organizations and Agencies (1965-1978)
Printed Material (1936, 1971-1978).

scopecontent.p: The minutes, correspondence, reports, surveys, newsletters, and printed material document the efforts of the Planned Parenthood League to provide birth control information and services to residents of the Detroit area and reflect the changing emphasis of the programs over the years. From its almost exclusive concentration on provision of contraceptive clinical services in its early years, Planned Parenthood came to offer such diverse programs as infertility counseling, a vasectomy service, sex education for teenagers and venereal disease detection. Correspondence with pharmaceutical companies in the 1960's and 1970's reflects the participation of Planned Parenthood League in tests of contraceptives, particularly oral contraceptives. Clinic surveys and statistical reports, along with information contained in annual reports (filed for the most part with board of directors minutes) document the medical services provided by the League.
Histories (1943-1949) consists of several short histories of the Detroit league and of the Michigan Birth Control League.

did.unittitle: Story of Birth Control in Michigan 1922-1943

scopecontent.p: The Board of Directors Records (1959-1978) consist primarily of minutes of meetings of the board of directors and of the executive committee, which are filed together for the years 1932 to 1965 and in two separate subseries for the years 1966 to 1978. Also included are scattered minutes and committee reports of annual meetings and several annual reports.

Committee Records (1959-1978) consist of scattered minutes of committee meetings, dating primarily from the late 1960's and 1970's. A more complete account of the activities of the various committees, however, is contained in reports presented at board meetings and filed with board of directors minutes.

did.unittitle: Nurses and Social Workers Advisory Committee 1965

scopecontent.p: Correspondence and Memoranda (1966-1979) consists of carbon copies of outgoing correspondence and of internal memoranda of Planned Parenthood League officials with staff members. Included are memoranda of Howard Lischeron, who was executive director from 1974 to 1977, and of Virginia Jones, who was assistant director. The fiftieth anniversary folder contains a booklet on the history of Planned Parenthood League entitled Courageous Crusade.

did.unittitle: Correspondence re 50th Anniversary of Planned Parenthood League 1972
Memoranda of Planned Parenthood League officials 1966-1968, 1974-1978

scopecontent.p: Medical Material (1932-1978) consists of three subseries: medical grants, clinic reports, and Department of Health, Education and Welfare applications. The medical grants subseries contains correspondence with pharmaceutical companies in the 1960's and 1970's regarding studies of contraceptives conducted at Planned Parenthood League clinics. Clinic reports includes statistical reports and surveys of clinic services. The HEW applications, which are filed in approximate chronological order, include proposals, budgets, and correspondence relating to the applications for funding, as well as evaluations of the programs that were conducted under the grants.

did.unittitle: Social Agency Referrals from a Planned Parenthood Clinic 1949-1950
Department of Health, Education, and Welfare Applications
Special Meeting of Executive Council August 20, 1971
Evaluation of Publicly Funded Family Planning Programs in Michigan 1971-1972, 1976
Southeastern Michigan Family Planning Project, Inc. 1972-1973
Southeastern Michigan Family Planning Project-Health, Education, and Welfare Health Service Funding Regulations 1975

scopecontent.p: Planned Parenthood Federation of America material (1954-1978) includes newsletters and memoranda from Planned Parenthood Federation of America and its research division, the Alan Guttmacher Institute. There isin addition, correspondence of Planned Parenthood League officials with other Planned Parenthood Federation of America affiliates.

did.unittitle: Great Lakes Coalition Meeting with Regional Congressional Delegation 1975
Planned Parenthood Association of Kent County 1967-1977 (scattered)
Planned Parenthood League of Monroe County 1965-1967
Planned Parenthood Association of Southwestern Mich. 1965-1967
Washtenaw County League for Planned Parenthood 1966-1977

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Organizations and Agencies series (1936-1978) contains correspondence and reports regarding various family planning programs and health agencies in Michigan.

did.unittitle: Center for Population Planning, University of Michigan
Wayne County Postpartum Family Planning Program 1966-1967
Job Survey of Family Planning Professionals 1969-1970
Conference on Family Planning in Michigan 1974-1975
Mayor's Committee for Human Resources Development, Detroit 1968-1972
Michigan Department of Health: Division of Maternal and Child Health 1965-1974 (scattered)
Macomb County Community Mental Health Services 1976-1977
Oakland County Community Mental Health Services Board 1967

scopecontent.p: Printed Material (1936, 1971-1978) includes a 1936 annual report of the maternal Health League of Michigan with a note on activities of the Detroit chapter; newsletters of Planned Parenthood League; and brochures and articles about birth control and family planning published by Planned Parenthood League, Planned Parenthood Federation of America, and related organizations.
